_exec_summary.SummaryText:
WESTERN PRECOOLING SYSTEMS/CAL WEST COOLING

CAL-ARP / RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN / PSM 5-YEAR UPDATE 2014



1. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.1  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies.

1.2  General Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances.

1.3  General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

1.4  Summary of the Five-Year Accident History.

1.5  Summary of the Emergency Response Program.

1.6  Planned Changes to Improve Safety.



1.1 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The Western Precooling Systems/Cal West Cooling (CWC) Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies are simply to not have accidental releases or emergencies. The Company endeavors to execute this policy through the daily implementation of its Safety Programs. The Company safety program includes, but is not limited to a comprehensive Process Safety Management Program (PSM), which is an integrated approach to the safe operation of processes using Regulated Substances. The PSM Program is specifically designed and intended to prevent accidental releases, and to deal safely with emergencies if and when they do happen. It is the goal of the company to protect its employees, visitors and neighbors from harm due to Company operations.



A "Non Responding Facility" policy has been adopted; however the Company recognizes the need to be prepared to safely deal with emergencies. A Hazardous Material Business Plan consistent with Emergency Action Plan requirements has been developed and includes emergency procedures, requirements, and information necessary to notify public response agencies and technical resources; the Staff communicate to the Fire Department and evacuate (or shelter-in-place) if there is a release situation or fire. Managers and employees would also shepherd visitors (truck drivers receiving product or delivering product). By effectively determining all persons are safe, the Fire D

epartment can more swiftly manage the tactical part of a response. It is the policy of the company that no-one shall respond to an emergency in a way that is beyond his or her level of training and responsibility.



The facility is supported by Western Precooling Systems (WPS) for ammonia refrigeration maintenance needs. The WPS Oxnard-area regional office and shop are both within 200 yards of the site. WPS supports HAZWOPER 1910.120 (q) and Refrigerating Engineers and Technicians (RETA) training for key Refrigerating Technicians and management personnel. These personnel are available to support Oxnard Fire/CUPA and the facility in the event of an emergency, and staff are on-call 24/7/365. Written procedures that include ammonia specific emergency pre-planning have been developed within the WPS "Thirty Minute Plan". Ammonia-specific emergency equipment is maintained at the WPS Service Shop and in WPS Refrigerating Technician's service vehicles. The company strives to execute its accidental release prevention & emergency response policies through appropriately skilled employees that are provided with adequate equipment and training.



A relationship with Oxnard Fire/CUPA has been established. Emergency response pre-planning is coordinated via regular site visits/inspections and submittal of appropriate EPCRA and other compliance reports. Compliance reports and submittals are updated in accordance with applicable requirements at predetermined intervals. Oxnard Fire/CUPA has also participated with WPS in PHAs in the Oxnard area. The WPS/CWC facility has confirmed that it is included in the Oxnard Community Emergency Plan, and key management personnel have received training in the Incident Command System (ICS).



1.2 General Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances



Cal West Cooling (CWC) is a facility located in Oxnard, CA in a commercial/industrial area of the city. The facility was built in the early 1970's on what were at that time the outs

kirts of the city, according to locally adopted codes in effect at that time. Improvements over the years have been made according to codes in effect at the time. Cal West Cooling is 100% owned by Western Precooling Systems but operations are separated:  Cal West Cooling manages pre-cooling and refrigerated storage and shipping of fresh produce; Western Precooling Systems supervises and maintains the refrigeration system.



The facility provides refrigeration effect for the removal of field heat from freshly harvested fruits and vegetables. The product that comes to the facility for pre-cooling and short-term storage is on site generally for four days from harvesting. The facility is a seasonally operated plant with product harvest periods picking up in the month of October and finishing in July. The remaining months see little fresh product, however the refrigeration equipment is still operative. Major maintenance is performed in the off-season. Operational maintenance is performed on a year-round basis. Company policy requires appropriately pre-qualified personnel to perform maintenance tasks.



The Regulated Substance in use is Anhydrous Ammonia, CAS #7664-41-7, which is used in a single closed-loop mechanical refrigeration system.  Refrigerating equipment consists of Compressor Units, Evaporative Condenser, Pressure Vessels, Room Evaporators, Portable HydroVac Vacuum Tubes, Pressure Coolers, Pumps, and associated valves, instrumentation and piping.  Pressure and temperature controls are installed in accordance with appropriate standards, including isolation and overpressure safety relief valves. Pressure relief valves terminate at an Ammonia-Water Diffusion System which protects these valves from venting directly to atmosphere.  An automated refrigeration control, monitoring and alarm system automatically monitors the system. The Alarm System is supervised 24/7/365 by a third party alarm company which maintains pre-determined call lists and parameters.  Techni

cians are also notified directly via .txt if the system approaches out-of tolerance conditions. Though rare, the facility has the ability to augment its capacity with portable refrigeration equipment according to seasonal harvest demand. Some of the facility equipment is also portable and may be used in other areas depending on geographical & seasonal harvest demand.  Portable refrigerating equipment is common in the industry.



1.3 General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



Accidental Release Prevention Program

The design of the refrigeration system along with the implementation of the PSM Accidental Release Prevention Program is designed to provide assurance that the risks associated with the ammonia refrigerant are effectively managed. The elements of the PSM Program are intended to be integrated with the ongoing functions of the facility. The program is specifically intended to prevent an occurrence and minimize the consequences of an Anhydrous Ammonia release. In California the PSM program is in accordance with CCR 8, 5189



Written procedures have been developed for the daily operation of ammonia-handling equipment, including the steps to be taken in the event of a release or threatened release. The written procedures include necessary safety precautions and address each operating phase as defined by the Cal-ARP RMP/PSM Program. Refrigeration systems are only operated by pre-qualified personnel that are trained and qualified in the relevant operating and safety procedures. The Written Operating Procedures are maintained online & on-site and are regularly validated for accuracy.



Scheduled inspections and maintenance are executed by Western Precooling Systems (WPS) qualified technicians and/or pre-qualified specialty vendors. WPS actively encourages its ammonia technicians to seek Certification through the Refrigerating Engineers and Technicians Association (RETA). WPS Technicians participate in a state of the a

rt online training program that includes RETA course materials (Web-based Business Manager/WBBM).



Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



Over the years it had become apparent in the Industry that a mishap while draining oil from the system was one of the most common release incidents to occur. Special self-closing valves are now installed as a permissive for oil drain flow. If a release were to develop during the oil-draining task, the mechanic simply releases the handle of the self-closing valve and flow is terminated. The facility has installed these types of valves at each of the system's oil drain points.  Modifications have been made to the piping system to provide support in the event of seismic activity. Relief valves have been piped to water absorbing tanks (dispersion/diffusion). Relief valve excursions were another unwanted release potential and by routing to a secondary containment system the effects of a relief situation have been mitigated.



Modifications have been made to the piping system that provides more support to the piping in the event of seismic activity. WPS has also reduced on and offsite consequence potential by piping pressure relief valves to an Ammonia-Water Diffusion System. Relief valve excursions were identified as another common unwanted release situation and by routing to a secondary containment system the effects of an overpressure and relief situation should no longer affect people on or off-site.



Other release prevention steps taken at WPS/CWC:

- CWC has enclosed the facility with fencing and gates to limit access to the facility to increase the security of the facility from potential "wrong-do-ers".

- Per the PSM Program access to process areas is controlled by a sign-in/sign-out program

- Employees are trained for hazard communication (discovery and communicating) for releases, fires,

vandals, etc.  Training is documented through an online training system (WBBM). 

- A strong relationship exists with the Oxnard Fire D

epartment. There have been demonstrations and tours of the system with the first responding engine companies to familiarize the crews with the facility layout and where hazardous areas are located.

- The engine room is computer controlled with telephone access for monitoring and parameter changes. The equipment may be shut down from offsite via phone if it were not possible to directly access the control area.

- There is an automatic texting function that is connected to the computer control.  When there is an equipment failure, or when the pressures are rising and approaching the shutdown setting, or if there is a power failure, a text alert is automatically sent to technicians and cooler managers.

- Staff is trained in the benefits of good housekeeping. The general appearance of the facility is maintained on a day-to-day basis.



1.4 Five-Year Accident History



There have been no qualifying accidental releases. There is no data to report.



1.5 The Emergency Response Program



The plant is specifically designed and engineered to provide for life safety and effective emergency response. Building space is fire-alarm, ammonia alarm and fire-sprinkler equipped. The refrigeration process' Control, Monitoring and Alarm System includes a backup power supply (UPS) and manual backup systems (kill switches). The system initiates notifications, alarms, equipment shutdown and pump-down of the affected area according to the location, nature and severity of the problem. Authorized personnel can access critical process system controls remotely. A KNOX system is coordinated and kept up to date via communications with the Oxnard Fire Department/CUPA. The automatic systems and devices are regularly inspected, tested and maintained. Employees are trained in manual discovery, emergency shutdown, evacuation and notification procedures in the highly unlikely event of a failure of the engineered safety and emergency systems.
